sentence: With cold and flu season bearing down on much of the U.S. amid the pandemic, consumers will once again be “nesting” in their homes in the months ahead, KeyBanc Capital Markets believes.
That’s good news for companies that can benefit from home-related spending.
The effects of the Covid-19 crisis have already drastically altered shoppers’ behavior, and analyst Bradley Thomas says a quick return to normal is unlikely.
“With a vaccine not likely to reach a large scale until the second half of 2021, we believe COVID-19’s impact on the consumer will largely continue through the quarters ahead,” he writes.

While high unemployment and economic uncertainty could have some consumers tightening their belts, that is somewhat offset by the fact that expenses related to travel, dining out, sporting events, and other entertainment have been severely curtailed, if not reduced to zero.
That leaves funds up for grabs.

“In fact, our math suggests the consumer has about $500 billion of discretionary dollars to shift into home-related spending from categories where spend has been significantly reduced,” Thomas writes.
He points to accelerating housing turnover, slightly improved consumer confidence, and lower gasoline prices as factors that could also help direct dollars toward at-home categories.

While risks remain, he notes that many companies have noted continuing strength in home goods, and recent relatively high savings rates among consumers could point to pent-up demand and greater spending power ahead.
As far as specific stocks that can benefit, Thomas has Overweight ratings on Lowe’s (LOW) and Tempur Sealy International (TPX), with price targets of $180 and $110.
At Home Group (HOME), Haverty Furniture Companies (HVT), Home Depot (HD), La-Z-Boy (LZB), Restoration Hardware parent RH (RH), and Sleep Number (SNBR) will also benefit, he says.
Thomas rates those stocks at Sector Weight.
